BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence. In addition an appreciable danger of wet and gliding avalanches exists.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a strong to storm force wind from northwesterly directions, sometimes large wind slabs formed especially above approximately 2300 m.
The near-surface layers of the snowpack can be released even by individual winter sport participants on wind-loaded slopes. Such avalanche prone locations are to be found also in places that are some distance from ridgelines and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain.

In particular in the regions exposed to the foehn wind further warming. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to increasing moistening of the snowpack. Medium-sized moist and wet avalanches are possible below approximately 2600 m, especially on very steep sunny slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
In some localities 10 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell on Monday above approximately 2200 m. Up to 2000 m rain has fallen. Until Friday the wind will be strong over a wide area.
Above the tree line snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. The upper section of the snowpack is unfavourably layered.
Naturally triggered avalanches and field observations confirm the complex avalanche situation in particular in the regions exposed to substantial precipitation.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The backcountry and freeriding conditions are to some extent unfavourable.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a strong wind from northwesterly directions, extensive wind slabs will form above the tree line. Avalanche prone locations are to be found on wind-loaded slopes and adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. As a consequence of the snowfall the prevalence and size of the avalanche prone locations will increase as the day progresses. At elevated altitudes the likelihood of avalanches being released is greater.
Individual medium-sized natural avalanches are not ruled out. This applies in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation, in particular in case of releases originating from very steep high-altitude and leeward starting zones.

As a consequence of the precipitation more frequent gliding avalanches are possible, even large ones in isolated cases. This applies in particular in all aspects below approximately 2600 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
On extremely steep slopes small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized wet loose snow avalanches are possible as a consequence of the rain.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 20 to 40 cm of snow will fall on Thursday. Up to the tree line rain will fall in some regions. This applies in particular in the west. In the east the snowfall level will be lower.

High altitudes and the high Alpine regions:
The northwesterly wind will transport the new snow significantly. Avalanche prone weak layers exist in the top section of the snowpack. The new snow and wind slabs are lying on the unfavourable surface of an old snowpack. Towards its base, the snowpack is largely stable.
Low and intermediate altitudes:
The rain will give rise to a loss of strength within the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Friday: The snowpack remains prone to triggering. 5 to 15 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall, especially in the northwest. The wind will be strong in some cases.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs represent the main danger. In addition there is a danger of wet snow slides and avalanches. Backcountry touring calls for meticulous route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of the strong northwesterly wind, fresh snow drift accumulations will form. These can be released by a single winter sport participant in particular on north to east to southeast facing aspects above approximately 2400 m. The wind slabs are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls and generally in the high Alpine regions. Caution is to be exercised at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack. From starting zones where no previous releases have taken place in particular the avalanches can in isolated cases reach large size. In particular adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large avalanches are possible. This applies in particular on very steep sunny slopes below approximately 2700 m, as well as on wind-loaded slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The strong wind will transport the fresh and old snow significantly. In particular at elevated altitudes snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. In some cases the wind slabs have bonded still only poorly with each other and the old snowpack. Individual weak layers exist in the snowpack on wind-loaded slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger will decrease gradually.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs represent the main danger. In addition there is a danger of wet snow slides and avalanches.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of a strong wind from northwesterly directions, clearly visible wind slabs will form in particular along the border with France. The avalanche prone locations for dry avalanches are to be found in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain above approximately 2500 m. More recent wind slabs are to be assessed with care and prudence. They can be released by a single winter sport participant in isolated cases in particular on very steep north, east and southeast facing slopes above approximately 2400 m, especially at their margins. As a consequence of warming during the day individual small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized avalanches are possible below approximately 3000 m. This applies in particular in case of releases originating from very steep, sunny starting zones that have retained the snow thus far.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The strong wind has transported some snow. Weak layers exist in the centre of the snowpack on steep shady slopes. In some cases the wind slabs have bonded still only poorly with each other and the old snowpack. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to increasing moistening of the snowpack in particular on steep east, south and west facing slopes below approximately 3000 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs represent the main danger. In addition there is a danger of wet snow slides and avalanches. Along the border with France the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent and larger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of a strong wind from northwesterly directions, sometimes easily released wind slabs will form. They can be released even by a single winter sport participant in particular on north to northeast to east facing aspects above approximately 2500 m, especially at their margins. The avalanche prone locations for dry avalanches are to be found in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain and at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack. These are to be avoided in particular in very steep terrain. As a consequence of warming during the day small and medium-sized dry and wet avalanches are possible below approximately 3000 m. This applies in particular in case of releases originating from very steep, sunny starting zones that have retained the snow thus far.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Up to 5 cm of snow has fallen. The strong wind has transported the fresh and old snow. In particular at elevated altitudes snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. Weak layers exist in the centre of the snowpack on steep shady slopes. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to increasing moistening of the snowpack below approximately 2300 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs represent the main danger. In addition an appreciable danger of wet snow slides and avalanches exists.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of a strong to storm force wind from northwesterly directions, hard wind slabs formed. They are to be assessed with care and prudence. In particular at intermediate and high altitudes the avalanche prone locations are more widespread.
The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant. In the regions neighbouring those that are subject to danger level 3 (considerable) the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent.
Such avalanche prone locations are to be found also in places that are some distance from ridgelines and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. Restraint should be exercised because avalanches can sweep people along and give rise to falls.
In particular in the regions exposed to the foehn wind further warming: Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to increasing and thorough wetting of the snowpack. Small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized moist and wet avalanches are possible below approximately 2600 m, especially on very steep sunny slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
In some localities 0 to 10 cm of snow fell on Monday above approximately 2200 m. Up to 2000 m rain has fallen. Until Friday the wind will be strong over a wide area. As a consequence of a strong to storm force northwesterly wind, rather small wind slabs formed. Above the tree line snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind.
Especially on steep sunny slopes as well as below approximately 2200 m less snow than usual is lying. Also adjacent to ridgelines hardly any snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs and weakly bonded old snow represent the main danger. Adjacent to ridgelines the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent and larger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of a strong wind from northwesterly directions, avalanche prone wind slabs will form. They can be released even by a single winter sport participant above the tree line. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain and at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack. These are to be avoided in particular in steep terrain.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The snowpack is largely stable.
The wind will transport the loosely bonded old snow. Wind slabs can in isolated cases be released by small loads. Weak layers exist in the snowpack.
Careful route selection and spacing between individuals are recommended.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a sometimes storm force wind from northwesterly directions, sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs will form on north and east facing slopes. Avalanche prone locations are to be found in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain above approximately 2200 m. At elevated altitudes the avalanche prone locations are a little more prevalent and exist in all aspects. The avalanche prone locations are and are barely recognisable because of the poor visibility. Avalanches can in particular reach medium size in isolated cases in the regions neighbouring those that are subject to danger level 3 (considerable).

More gliding avalanches are possible, even large ones in isolated cases, in particular on steep east, south and west facing slopes below approximately 2600 m, in particular in the regions with a lot of snow. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
On extremely steep slopes individual mostly small wet loose snow avalanches are possible as a consequence of the rain.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 5 to 15 cm of snow, and up to 20 cm in some localities, will fall on Thursday. Up to intermediate altitudes rain will fall.

High altitudes and the high Alpine regions:
The northwesterly wind will transport the new snow and, in some cases, old snow as well. The fresh wind slabs will be deposited on soft layers at elevated altitudes. They are in some cases prone to triggering.
Towards its base, the snowpack consists of faceted crystals. The snowpack will be subject to considerable local variations above the tree line.

Low and intermediate altitudes:
The rain will give rise to a loss of strength within the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Some snow will fall. Wind slabs represent the main danger.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh and older wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The wind slabs of the last few days must be evaluated with care and prudence in all aspects above the tree line. These can be released even by a single winter sport participant.
The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls in all aspects.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: More recent wind slabs are poorly bonded with the old snowpack above the tree line. The spring-like weather conditions on Wednesday gave rise to moistening of the snowpack below approximately 2600 m. Snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. Weak layers in the old snowpack necessitate caution and restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As a consequence of mild temperatures and the moderate to strong northwesterly wind, fresh snow drift accumulations will form on Friday.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs above approximately 2000 m. In the last few days the wind slabs have increased in size once again.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant on northeast to north to northwest facing aspects above approximately 2500 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Wind slabs can still in isolated cases be released by small loads and reach medium size. Careful route selection and spacing between individuals are recommended.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs are only small and can only be released by large loads in most cases.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The small wind slabs of the last few days can be released in isolated cases on very steep shady slopes above approximately 2400 m. The wind slabs are clearly recognisable to the trained eye. Restraint should be exercised because avalanches can sweep people along and give rise to falls.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: As a consequence of mild temperatures and solar radiation the snow drift accumulations stabilised. The snowpack will be generally stable. Towards its base, the snowpack consists of faceted crystals. The snowpack will be subject to considerable local variations above the tree line.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights:
The wind slabs of the last few days represent the main danger.
The weather will be mild over a wide area.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls above the tree line. Medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large natural avalanches are possible.
The wind slabs can be released in isolated cases in all aspects at elevated altitudes.
As a consequence of warming during the day, the likelihood of natural moist avalanches being released will increase gradually in particular on steep sunny slopes at intermediate and high altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The wind slabs are lying on weak layers. Towards its base, the snowpack is largely stable. The solar radiation will give rise as the day progresses to increasing moistening of the snowpack.
In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the hard snow surface.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released in isolated cases, especially at their margins. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. Mostly avalanches are small.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on steep shady slopes. The old snowpack will be quite stable.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: In particular in the south and at the base of rock walls small and medium-sized moist loose snow avalanches are possible as a consequence of warming.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of warming and solar radiation, the natural avalanche activity will increase. Moist avalanches can occur naturally.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack will become generally well bonded.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The more recent wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. Mostly avalanches are small.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: More recent wind slabs are poorly bonded with the old snowpack above the tree line. The spring-like weather conditions on Wednesday gave rise to moistening of the snowpack. Weak layers in the old snowpack necessitate caution and restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As a consequence of mild temperatures and the moderate to strong northwesterly wind, fresh snow drift accumulations will form on Friday.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The weather will be mild over a wide area.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of warming, the likelihood of natural moist avalanches being released will increase gradually in particular on steep sunny slopes. Small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized natural avalanches are possible.
The wind slabs can be released, especially by large additional loads,. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain and adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to increasing moistening of the snowpack.
In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the hard snow surface.
Below approximately 1500 m only a little snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The mostly small wind slabs can be released in isolated cases, but mostly only by large additional loads, in particular on north to northeast to southeast facing aspects above approximately 2500 m. As a consequence of warming during the day mostly small avalanches are possible below approximately 2500 m. This applies in particular in case of releases originating from very steep, sunny starting zones that have retained the snow thus far.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The snowpack is largely stable and its surface has a crust that is strong in many cases. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to increasing moistening of the snowpack below approximately 2500 m.
In all regions only a small amount of snow is lying for the time of year.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wet snow represents the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation individual mostly small moist and wet avalanches are possible above approximately 1800 m. Caution is to be exercised in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain, as well as on very steep sunny slopes. In high Alpine regions there will be only a slight increase in the danger.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: At intermediate altitudes a little snow is lying. The sometimes strong wind has transported some snow. In gullies and bowls the wind slabs are larger. These are to be found especially at high altitude. The weather conditions will give rise to significant moistening of the snowpack also at high altitude.
